intro: Centranthus calcitrapae var. macrosiphon, commonly known as the large-siphon centranthus, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, white to pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and thrives in full sun. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, while its flowers are arranged in umbels, typical of the family. This variety is distinguished by its larger, more prominent floral structures compared to other centranthus species.
